unnormalised: Okay, let's talk fuel efficiency, yaars! As petrol prices keep going up-up-up, everyone's suddenly a "mileage ka king" wannabe, right? So, I thought, let's break it down, desi style. We're not talking some fancy international standards here, just real-world tips for getting the most kilometres out of your scooter/bike/car.
normalised: Okay, let's talk fuel efficiency, yes! As petrol prices keep going up, everyone's suddenly a "mileage ka king" wannabe, right? So, I thought, let's break it down, desi style. We are not talking some fancy international standards here, just real-world tips for getting the most kilometers out of your scooter slash bike slash car.

unnormalised: First up, tyre pressure. Seems simple, but loads of people ignore it. Check your tyre pressure regularly! Under-inflated tyres increase rolling resistance, which means you're burning extra fuel. Your owner's manual will tell you the correct pressure, usually around 30-32 psi for bikes and 32-35 psi for cars. That's pounds per square inch, okay?

Your owner's manual will tell you the correct pressure, usually around thirty to thirty two P-S-I for bikes and thirty two to thirty five P-S-I for cars. That's pounds per square inch, okay?

unnormalised: Next, think about your driving style. Aggressive acceleration and braking are fuel guzzlers. Try to maintain a steady speed. Highway cruising at 80 kmph is way more efficient than constantly weaving through traffic and slamming on the brakes. Imagine you're carrying a glass of lassi – smooth and steady wins the race!
normalised: Next, think about your driving style. Aggressive acceleration and braking are fuel guzzlers. Try to maintain a steady speed. Highway cruising at eighty kilometer per hour is way more efficient than constantly weaving through traffic and slamming on the brakes. Imagine you are carrying a glass of lassi – smooth and steady wins the race!

unnormalised: Proper maintenance is key. Get your vehicle serviced regularly. A dirty air filter, clogged fuel injectors, or old spark plugs can significantly reduce fuel efficiency. Think of it like this: a well-maintained engine is like a well-oiled vada pav- delicious and efficient! Change the oil when the manual says, usually after every 5000 km or 6 months, whatever comes first.

Think of it like this: a well-maintained engine is like a well-oiled vada pav- delicious and efficient! Change the oil when the manual says, usually after every five thousand kilometer or six months, whatever comes first.

unnormalised: Weight matters! Carrying unnecessary weight in your vehicle reduces fuel efficiency. That extra 20 kg of stuff in your boot might not seem like much, but it adds up. Clear out all the junk you don't need – old newspapers, unused tools, that cricket bat you haven't touched in months. Treat your vehicle like you treat your stomach – avoid unnecessary baggage!

unnormalised: Also, plan your route. Avoid peak hour traffic whenever possible. Stop-start traffic is a major fuel killer. Use Google Maps or other navigation apps to find the shortest and least congested route. And remember, a longer route at a consistent speed is often more fuel-efficient than a shorter route stuck in bumper-to-bumper traffic.

unnormalised: Idling is a silent fuel thief. If you're going to be stopped for more than a minute, turn off the engine. This is especially important at traffic lights. Many modern cars have auto start-stop systems that do this automatically, saving you precious milliliters of petrol.

unnormalised: Finally, fuel quality matters. Use good quality fuel from a reputable petrol pump. Adulterated fuel can damage your engine and reduce fuel efficiency. And don’t just fill up the tank when it's almost empty. Keep it topped up to about 3/4 full to minimize fuel evaporation, especially during the hot summer months when the temperature can reach 48°C. Happy driving, and save those rupees!
